ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot about transatlantic slave narratives and their influence on future literature.
Great reading list and Homans is excellent at engaging us in discussion.
I learned a lot about analyzing seemingly disparate works as connected, and considering the implicit conversations between them.
Evidence-based discussion skills, literary analysis, writing academic papers that draw connections between works, research

This was the first course I took that focused on reading literature through the lens of race and gender. I think it was very important for me to develop my ability to see through that lens, and to analyze how race and gender roles play out in literature.
I developed my close reading skills, and thought about connections between works of literature that I might not have put in conversation before.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: We read a lot in the course, which for me was a strength, but I think the conversation could have done with a bit more guidance.
Only improvement could be more interesting paper topics but great readibg list and must experience professor.

I thought the syllabus was great. The discussions sometimes lagged a bit--we would get caught on a particular idea or question and then have a very difficult time moving on to something else, even if as a whole we didn't find that particular idea or question all that engaging. I think there could have been a more natural flow to our discussions.

I loved the texts from this course! Discussion was consistently engaging; although it lagged towards the last few weeks of the semester, I think this could easily be fixed by weekly reading responses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This class is a lot of reading, but really rewarding, especially at the end of the semester! I definitely learned a lot and Professor Homans is great.
If you're interested in the works on the syllabus, or more broadly in questions of race and gender in literature, it's a solid class.
Absolutely! The topic of this course is relevant, and Margaret Homans is not only a phenomenal professor, but she is also kind and approachable.

Yes, definitely take this course. Professor Homans is great--clear in her expectations, astute in her observations--and for those who have never taken a class like this before, it will expand your literary vocabulary and your ability to see things through the lens of race and gender.
I would absolutely recommend this class-- reasonable workload, amazing reading list, and Professor Homans is great and makes for an engaging and energizing seminar environment.

extras.title:
WGSS 224 01/ENGL 226 01
        Race and Gender in Transatlant
